content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good description, fun and original puzzle, easy to solve. Nice!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is clear. 
Maybe this is on the harder side of being 'easy', so if success rate becomes low then a reassignment to 'medium' might be recommended.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The goal is a little hard to understand on first read but makes sense after a re-read.  I was able to complete it in C# with a few lines of code.
I'd appreciate feedback on the difficulty and how to tag this. I don't think it's a hard algorithm but it may not really be off the shelf either.

Output
* Suggest to repeat here / clarify that [[jackpot]] refers to the largest prize that can be won. (The goal can be easy to miss because of how that last sentence in Goal section is phrased; also it seems that jackpot can mean a large prize instead of the top prize.)

Thanks.
It feels like dynamic programming to me.
You are correct, the success rate has been falling. It's not yet below 50% but it feels appropriate to reclassify.

Bruteforce times out from test "Large" onwards (which is good), so to me it is medium difficulty.

Also, can you please change stub generator from:
read prize1:int
loop height read prize:int
To:
loop height+1 read prize:int
Or:
loop (height+1) read prize:int

I wish I could. The stub code looks like it would work, but the webpage javascript doesn't know how to interpret it and won't let me test or save. Do you know how to circumvent? A couple of years ago it was possible to write something that didn't match, but no longer.
Oh you are right, that's unfortunate.. @5DN1L do you know if there is a cleaner workaround ?
Change the input value of [[height]] to [[height]] + 1 instead? I don't know how clean (or confusing) that is.

No, we are talking about the stub generator reading one line in var prize1 and height lines in a loop instead of reading (height + 1) lines in one loop.

Edit: my bad, you are talking about the same thing.. but then the problem is with the first read loop.

I mean there's no way to change the stub. A possible (not saying whether it's good or bad) workaround is to change the value of [[height]] to [[height]] + 1 and then change a few more affected descriptions.
The variable [[height]] is needed for the number of rows of increments. I did think about listing both, but that feels awkward.
Or maybe just add another input variable [[n_prizes]].
Perhaps just list all prizes on one line (thus one read in the stub generator) and let the users split the line themselves ?
In that case the line would have to be a string. I don't think there's a perfect solution. Actually there is, your original idea, but I would have to bypass the javascript somehow.

I mean, one long string that needs to be split is done on a lot of puzzles. For most languages, they just do [int(x) for x in input().split(' ')] or equivalent, and in c++ we do while (cin) cin >> value; to read them all so it works out.

Yes, but the stub code won't generate [int(x) for x ...] or while (cin) ... unless I use loopline, and I similarly can't use loopline because it needs to know how many. So what you would end up with is reading the whole line as prizes = input(). I'd rather have some notion that they're ints.
Fair enough. To get back to the difficulty, I maintain this is medium to me.

Well, I myself prefer to be slightly more "verbose" and suggest you (the author) to add an input variable of [[n_prizes]] to avoid confusion/complaints like this one:
https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-pachinko-jackpot-puzzle-discussion/205561/2

… and it's also for the benefit to a newbie attempting this puzzle; this is, after all, categorised as an Easy puzzle.

Or at the very least, add something like this to the stub (the word STATEMENT is just a keyword and won't be shown in the actual default code):

STATEMENT
In the default code, the first prize is read first
before the rest of the prizes are read in a loop
because of a limitation in CodinGame's stub generation.
